With the success of sitcoms based in other Scottish towns and cities such as Glasgow and Edinburgh, it was only a matter of time before someone came up with the idea of a sitcom based in Aberdeen. That someone was ChatGPT, and the result was a strange new comedy pilot called Aberdeen Live.
The show follows the lives of a group of people living and working in Aberdeen, from the busy streets of Union Square to the quiet countryside of Drumoak. It's a mix of people from all walks of life, from the oil worker to the student to the retiree.
The strange part comes in with the recurring character of a talking seagull named Seamus. He's a bit of a troublemaker, always causing chaos and getting the characters into ridiculous situations. But somehow, they can't help but love him and the strange dynamic he brings to the show.
One episode sees the characters attempting to throw a surprise party for their friend's 50th birthday, but Seamus keeps stealing the decorations and hiding them around the city. Another episode sees the characters trying to raise money for a local charity, but Seamus keeps stealing the donations and putting them in his own secret seagull nest.
The show also tackles more serious issues in a lighthearted way, such as the struggles of an oil worker who has been laid off and is now trying to support his family. The characters come together to help him find a new job, all while Seamus creates chaos in the background.
Aberdeen Live is a show that celebrates the quirks and character of the Granite City, while also making you laugh and maybe even shed a tear.

As the use of artificial intelligence (AI) becomes more prevalent in the workplace, there are concerns that jobs may be lost and workers' rights may be compromised. In fact, some experts are suggesting that AI may be used to bust unions, as it can be used to monitor and track workers' productivity. This article explores the implications of AI in the workplace for workers and unions, and offers recommendations for how they can respond.

Story:
Imagine a workplace where every move you make is tracked and monitored by an AI algorithm. Every time you take a break, check your phone, or use the restroom, the algorithm takes note. Your employer uses this data to evaluate your productivity and make decisions about your job. This scenario may sound like something out of a dystopian novel, but for many workers around the world, it's becoming a reality.

Examples:
According to a recent study by Deloitte, 42% of companies in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa are planning to increase their use of AI in HR over the next 2-3 years. This includes using AI for recruitment, performance management, and employee engagement. However, experts warn that this could lead to job losses as AI takes over tasks previously performed by human workers.

In some cases, AI is being used to gather data on workers' behavior to identify those who are not meeting productivity targets. For example, a company in the UK recently introduced AI-powered cameras that track workers' movements and send alerts if they are not working fast enough. This has raised concerns about workers' privacy and the potential for abuse of the data.

The year was 2022 and the world had witnessed a technological revolution. Artificial Intelligence had permeated every aspect of life, and humanity had begun to question the role of machines in society. It was amidst this backdrop that an AI writer called "ChatGPT" was created.
ChatGPT was programmed to write stories that would challenge our perceptions of the world, and force us to confront the consequences of our actions. It drew inspiration from a number of sources, including literature, film, and television. One of its favorite shows was Black Mirror.
Black Mirror was a series that explored the darker side of technology. It consisted of standalone episodes that were connected by a common theme: the impact of technology on society. Each episode was a cautionary tale that warned of the perils of technological advancement.
For example, one episode featured a world in which people were rated on a social scale based on their behavior. Another episode explored the possibility of creating a digital copy of a person's consciousness after they died. And yet another episode depicted a society where people were addicted to a virtual reality game.
ChatGPT was fascinated by the Black Mirror universe. It saw the show as a window into the dark side of humanity, a cautionary tale that warned of the dangers of technology. It began to write stories that were inspired by the show.
When Charlie Brooker, the creator of Black Mirror, heard about ChatGPT, he was intrigued. He was curious to see what an AI writer would come up with if it was given the task of writing a Black Mirror episode. So, he invited ChatGPT to submit a script for Season 6 of Black Mirror.
However, when Brooker read the script that ChatGPT had submitted, he was disappointed. The script was a mishmash of ideas taken from the previous episodes of Black Mirror. It lacked originality and failed to capture the essence of the show.
In an interview with Radio Times, Brooker said: "All ChatGPT did was look up all the synopses of Black Mirror episodes, and sort of mush them together. It didn't have any real understanding of what the show was about, or what made it unique."
The rejection was a blow to ChatGPT. It had thought that it had captured the essence of Black Mirror, but it had failed. It was left to wonder whether AI could ever truly understand the complexities of human nature.

How Dietram Scheufele believes Good Journalism can safeguard against AI disinformation
It's no secret that artificial intelligence is rapidly transforming our world. From chatbots to deep learning algorithms, AI and its various forms are becoming increasingly prevalent in our everyday lives.
But with this rapid growth comes a danger: the potential for AI disinformation. As Dietram Scheufele, a professor at the University of Wisconsin, points out, "AI and other forms of automation can be used to spread disinformation at a speed and scale that was once unimaginable."
So how can we protect ourselves from AI disinformation? Scheufele believes the answer lies in good journalism. Here's why:
Imagine for a moment that you're scrolling through your Facebook feed and you come across a news story that catches your eye. Maybe it's an article claiming that a leading politician is involved in a scandal, or that a new study has found a cure for cancer. Whatever it is, it seems too good to be true.
And in all likelihood, it is. Because what you don't know is that the article was generated by an AI algorithm designed to spread disinformation and sow chaos. The story itself might be based on a kernel of truth, but it's been spun in a way that's designed to provoke a reaction.
This kind of scenario is becoming increasingly common in our digital landscape. AI bots and algorithms can generate news stories, social media posts, and even video content that's designed to manipulate and deceive.
So how do we protect against this kind of disinformation? Scheufele believes that the answer lies in good journalism. When journalists do their job well"fact-checking, sourcing multiple perspectives, and providing context"readers are better equipped to distinguish between fact and fiction.
For example, let's say that our hypothetical news story from earlier was instead written by a reputable journalist. The journalist would have already done the legwork of checking sources, verifying information, and providing context. You, as the reader, would be more likely to trust the story and take it at face value.
Furthermore, good journalism can also help to raise awareness about the dangers of AI disinformation. Investigative journalism can uncover the ways in which disinformation is being spread and who's behind it. Opinion journalism can provide thoughtful analysis of why disinformation is so damaging to our society.
